summary: the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 has been described as a highly contagious viral disease in several avian species. the disease is characterized by high morbidity and mortality and could be potentially contracted by humans and other warm-blooded animals. this is caused by the pathogenic subtypes H5 and H7 but with the circulating H5N1and H7N9 is causing major problems across the globe. 12 african countries (Figure-1) have been infected by this deadliest subtype. the first wave of HPAI H5N1 outbreak started in 2006, through 2007and ended in 2008. however, there were only single outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 between 2006 and 2016, which was reported in 2006. the risk of introduction of HPAI was estimated as low for Benin and Togo and negligible for Cameroon, Senegal, and Guinea. the virus has been endemic since December 2014. it has been circulated non-stop in poultry since 2006 and 2016. the virus has evolved into multiple genetic lineages that differ antigenically. researchers have reiterated several times that there are fewer domestic waterfowls in Africa than in Asia. but it remains unclear whether the available few waterfowls can perpetuate the
